ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: I interacted with Marlyse Duguid and Julius Pasay equally. Both were really knowledgeable and helpful.
Both Marlyse and Julius were equally helpful.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was great! Very helpful and organized extra review sessions to accommodate students concerns about the exams.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Julius and Marlyse were great!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Julius Pasay
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  She is awesome.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  she is really helpful
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid (also interacted a lot with Julius)
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is great!!!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marylse Duguid and Julius Pasay
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  MD
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Julius was also great!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  She's the best!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  And Julius!!

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Both Marlyse and Julius were very helpful to me. Clearly very knowledgeable, they also made themselves very accessible and seemed to really care about our experience. Thanks!
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  I have been helped a lot in terms of understanding lecture contents and logistics of field trips.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Prof. Ashton's lectures did not prepare you for the tests and his tests were not comprehensive (or very good). The readings are poor but the field trips are worthwhile and the TFs were great in the field and the review sessions.
NA

Overall I learned a LOT from this course. The lectures, readings, field trips, and various tests all really helped me synthesize my understanding of silviculture. Here is my general feedback:1) I think all the readings should just be posted online; there were several books that were on hold in the library, but it would be so easy to just get these online.2) There are, in my opinion, too many field trips. I think it would be better to concentrate the field trips into 2-day excursions instead of having all these 1/2 day field trips. They also inevitably always ran several hours behind schedule, and although the TA tried to keep things on track, I felt that more consideration could have been put into making sure things stayed on track time-wise. I also think sometimes the field trips were too crowded.3) This course is a lot of work overall and very logistically complicated; I know it's worth 4 credits, but I felt like it took up more time than any other course I've had at FES - maybe this could be rectified by figuring out a more strategic way to condense the various field trips.

Course content and structure were great. But lectures were often hard to follow. A lot of information was presented, but it was hard to assimilate without a big picture schematic (of say the relationship between shade tolerance and regeneration methods). Half of the field trips were very useful, but the lessons from the first few were a bit unclear. Also, since the lectures were filmed, the lecture atmosphere was a little odd/formal, and there wasn't as much conversation that would have been useful.
Must-take class at FES- well taught, good TAs, great fieldtrips.
Best class I've taken here at Yale.
Question 8--Field trip times could pretty much be cut in half. Mark tended to talk for too long. What he said is definitely useful--it just could be said much faster.

5-6: the teaching fellows (Marlyse and Julius) were outstanding. They were both incredibly knowledgeable, prepared, and helpful.8: I was always incredibly cold on field trips, which made it very difficult for me to concentrate and learn much. Shorter field trips would have been much appreciated.

Field trips - I think some of the trips had too much talking in them which could have been done in the classrooms where it would have been easier to pay attention. I aslo think more practicing applying prescriptions would have been really helpful and enjoyable, even if it was just on campus.

The instructor and teaching fellows were fantastic! They were always willing and excited to answer any and all questions. As someone with no background in this subject this helped me feel comfortable learning about a subject I was interested in but completely out of my element.
Although the field trips are numerous, they are extremely helpful in synthesizing conceptual material discussed in lecture.

This course was incredibly interesting and valuable. A great mix of theory and application, I felt that it synthesized and tied together many interests of mine. I really appreciated Mark's teaching style and felt that the way he presented materials worked well for me.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trips were by far my favorite parts of the course, specifically the ones where we did concrete exercises.
This was a very comprehensive course, and very well taught. Provided a lot of information that is applicable to a number of different contexts.

The field trips were excellent! Though they were very time consuming, they were worth it. The field exercises and meeting with practitioners really helped us solidify the material we were learning in class.

The field trip to Yale-Myers was amazing and I learned more during that weekend than during any other part of the course because it allowed an application of the classroom information to a managed forest.
Field TripsTFs
Quality of the teaching staff.
The field trips. They were very helpful for me to understand the concept that I learned in the class.

Mark is an incredible storyteller, and I have a lot of respect for his grasp of the material. His lectures are entertaining and mostly easy to follow. The field trips were a great learning experience. The readings are overall really helpful, especially the Silviculture book. Marlyse and Julius were really open to questions.
The field trips were informative and useful for gaining a real-world understanding of concepts taught in class.
Gaining a foundational understanding of silvicultural dynamics, which I hope to build on. The field trip to Yale-Myers was particularly instructive.
Learning various techniques through field trip.
Best aspects are understanding silvicultural treatments and visit them on site.
Fieldtrips- by far. There could even be more of them!
Field trips were one of the best aspects of this course. Mark is a great teacher in the field, and was able to reinforce many of the concepts that we covered in lecture.
The field trips were critical for truly understanding the concepts discussed in class.
Professors mastery of the material.
Field trips and being in the field with Mark. Hands down best class of the year.
Doing practice prescriptions in the field then getting immediate feedback. The field trips overall were great. That was where I learned the most information.
Mark is an incredible lecturer!
Mark Ashton
The passion and enthusiasm dr. Ashton brought to all his lectures.
Field trips, exercises, and prescriptions.

The way the course built off of a strong ecological foundation. The first month or so was all background ecology and botany. This allowed us to think in a divergent way when it came to application, much more useful than memorizing prescriptions for certain scenarios. Mark encouraged a diversity of "answers" to his questions, emphasizing the highly contextual nature of applied ecology. This is a great service to students who may be used to being spoon-fed answers.
I could apply concepts learned from lectures to field via field trips. It was fun to learn how to read forests.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: While I loved the field trips, sometimes they could take longer than they needed to. Additionally, even when it was cold earlier in the semester, it would have been good to do more exercises in the field instead of just talking.
I thought the class went really well. I don't have any recommendations.
The lectures could be more focused and concise. The class would benefit from being smaller and having more TF-student interaction.
Probably too much material; could split into two courses?
None. Mark Ashton, Marlyse, and this class were awesomely organized.
See response to question #15.
Additional hands-on exercises.

Some of the lectures feel outdated. Also, it would be great to cover a little more forest ecology and delve into structure-based management like what the USFS and BLM are transitioning to in the Pacific NW (maybe assign more of the critique of silviculture book, or talk about franklin / johnson ecological forestry?)

In lectures, plant and location names are often not printed on the slides. Although I tried to record important names as well as possible, proper spelling would have made it easier to study before exams.

Although the field trips were excellent and crucial, it would be better if they could have been more evenly spaced throughout the semester so that we didn't end up out in the field every single Friday after Spring Break.
The lectures can ramble, but that didn't bother me.

Lecture time could also be cut down. Mark tends to talk for half an hour on the first two slides then misses out on telling us valuable information at the end of the lecture. It's hard to pay attention after the first hour.
Field trips were too long and cold!
More opportunities for practicing prescriptions. Just seeing it once is not enough.

The field trips were great. They helped me to conceptualize in class materials. I would recommend doing a few example prescriptions before the midterm and then full prescriptions before the practical.

It was a little unclear on a couple of the field trips what their specific objectives were. That being said, they were all interesting.I think being a little choosier with the assigned readings may have created a situation that was a little less intimidating to those debating whether to do them. I did most of the readings and found them valuable, though they took a substantial amount of time (the silviculture text was especially useful).
The concepts are pretty tricky to understand right away.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There were no discussions/ lab sections.
Yes the lectures and field trips were paired well, though the field trips were more instructive.
It was very effective!

Yes, the majority of the field trips solidified the course material. It would have been nice to not have so many field trips packed in at the end of the semester and more spread out; they were great, but concentrated too heavily at the end.
Awesome- they work well together.

It would have been nice had the discussions with the TFs been a bit more structured. They held a Q&A session, which was very helpful, but sometimes it can be heard to know which questions to ask, so it would have been great if there had been a presentation in other words of some of the material covered in the lectures.
Field trips were great.
The timing of the field trips usually lined up perfectly with lecture topics--that definitely helps the lectures sink in!

Yes, very effective. I think if we had a handout with each field trip outlining the specific lectures and topics we were touching on could be helpful.I created this structure to my learning in the course and found that studying for the exams was simplified and the field trips took on a great deal of relevance and meaning when put in the context of our lectures.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Marlyse conveys material clearly and directly. She's very knowledgeable in the field. I could say the same about Julius.
Always quick to provide answers easy to engage with
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Teaching assistants were great and really accessible and knowledgeable.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Both Julius and Marlyse were excellent teaching assistants. They really went out of their way to help us before exams and were always happy to answer questions.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  I have nothing more to say about Marlyse. She is already super awesome as a Teaching Fellow. One of the best teaching fellows that I have ever encountered with.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is very knowledgable and incredibly patient in answering questions. She is very responsive to email and willing to take extra time if you need something explained. I would say it would have been helpful if she could coordinate with Mark a bit more in assessing the material on the mid-term, prescription and final exams - I'm not sure if this is possible. I thought the study sessions were helpful, but could have been made more so if there were at least some general questions outlined to structure the discussion.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is clear, organized, and responsive. Her knowledge of the material is obviously impressive, and she prepares students effectively for assignments and exams.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse and Julius explained the material really well and were approachable.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Strengths: understanding the topic, open to have extra sessions with the students, organized
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Super knowledgable, best TA ever.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was a great resource during class, and her review sessions before exams were especially helpful.

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  It's tough to evaluate Marlyse this semester because of her dissertation defense, but like in Stand Dynamics she was still a rockstar. Tutorials with her were always helpful, even when they weren't at the best time.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse and Julius were amazing. They were both incredibly organized and helpful.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse and Julius are da bomb
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Pretty much all strengths. She was knowledgeable and available. I can't think of a way to improve at the moment. Thanks Marlyse!

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am interested in forest policy and politics, so this course was really great to get a grounding in how forest management actually works in practice to add depth to my knowledge.
Required course for Master of Forestry degree, and a sort of central pillar to the topic of forestry, so it is very relevant and a required course.

Silviculture fit into my overall program because I am interested in land and wildlife conservation in New England. Forestry is a huge part of New England land management so it was very useful to learn more about this topic.
I am an undergraduate and was recently admitted into the 5th year program at FES. I am particularly interested in land management and this course was a great introduction to management of forests.
It is unclear.
Part of the MF program.
The class was very useful for me to understand the ecological aspect of the forest and to write silviculture prescription. It is one of the core courses to master the forest management.

It's a critical course for the Master of Forestry degree. I wanted to take it to have a better understanding of silviculture prescriptions so that I can ultimately know how to assess various prescriptions and know how to envision different management alternatives. Also, to acquire a better understanding of terminology.
Silviculture is a foundation for my studies in sustainable natural resource management and raw materials sourcing.
Perfect fit with the MF curriculum, although a silviculture 2 would really cement the deal.

I took this course as a second year interested in sustainable land management, and wish that I had taken it during the spring of my first year. It provided a great foundation in silviculture and forest management, that I hope to build on in the future.
It is the cornerstone of the MF program. Without it I wouldn't feel comfortable earning a degree from FES.
Restoration is my focus.
Silviculture is fundamental to the practice of forestry. Without this course I would not feel confident to further pursue a career in forestry. Also, it is a great introduction for forest processes.

This course convinced me that land management is fascinating. If I had taken this course during the fall I would have switched to the MF program! Short of that, the knowledge and experience I gained in the course are essential to my research efforts. If more advanced versions of this course were offered I would take them all.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was told to take a really good silviculture class to be successful in my field.
See above.
I took this course because I am interested in Land Management particularly in New England.
It was highly recommended by previous students and I was very interested in learning about forest management and dynamics.
I wanted to learn about Forestry management.
Part of the MF program.
I wanted to learn on the silviculture prescription and how to manage forest.
same answer as above.
see above
Requirement in graduration
Required and well regarded.
I hadnât taken a general forestry course yet at FES, and felt that this was an important area of knowledge to cover for natural resources management.
It is required of the MF program.

I was curious to learn something about trees, I want to manage my family's small woodlot some day, and I felt that it just wasn't right to graduate from the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies without some knowledge of forestry.
Because restoration is my focus and I want Mark Ashton to be my friend.
I am interested in conservation and how to best manage forests for wildlife

I took this course to better understand how forests work. Also, I took this course to reinforce what I had learned from stand dynamics. Finally, I took this course to understand the concepts behind the forest operations I have witnessed and hope to employ in the future.

I heard many good reviews from 2nd year students. Also, the title "Applied Ecology..." seemed to match perfectly with my interests. Also, Mark gave a very interesting, inspiring lecture during MODs (and I had heard good things about his teaching).

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes they did.
Yes? Although the class also reveals that there's a still lot left to learn and be able to apply, especially, but this demands experience more than anything
The knowledge and skills I gained in this course exceeded my expectations. I feel like we all came away with a really good understanding of how to look at a forest as an ecologist and forester.
Yes!
Yes andno. I wish there had been more discussion of the biology of forests. But the topics were for the most part very interesting.
Yes.
Beyond my expectation. The best class during my first year.
Yes, definitely.
Yes.
Yes
Yes,, more than my expectation
Pretty much- although at times it felt a bit slow. Would like more of the current thinking / science on prescriptions, particularly examples of thinning and variable retention.

Yes, as an introductory course I think this class gave me a broad set of tools and knowledge that can be applied to forestry and land management. I plan to build on this foundation through professional experience and continuing education.
Yes, definitely. I didn't learn very clearly how to take a forest stand and numerically calculate how much and what to cut, but that's not what I was hoping to get out of the course.
Far and beyond.
Yes. The natural regeneration/ harvesting methods section was the most interesting and worthwhile topic of any class I took this semester.
yes
Yes.
Yes! This will be incredibly useful and also sparked my interests in forestry so I plan on taking more courses
Yes.
More than met my expectations.
Yes now I feel more comfortable to work in forests.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Discussion and sharing of ideas.
Advantage: I learned from other people, especially getting their perspectives.Disadvantage: I tended to left behind because I could not follow their paces.
Always helpful to pool knowledge and perspectives from others when working on the same issue.
before mid term and final examination
It was helpful to review for exams in a group because questions I hadn't thought of were raised by other people.
Approaching problems from different perspectives really added to the field work.

I did a little studying in a group. I could have done fine on my own, but felt that it would be more fun/interesting to study in a group. Not totally necessary, but I also kept up with the readings and felt prepared for the exams on my own. I did get some critical help with the quantitative element of the course from my study group.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's a really great course if you want to learn the basics of silviculture, and its great if you don't have much experience.
Go on the field trips! They are very helpful for visualizing and understanding much of what is discussed in lecture.
I would recommend this course to anyone even remotely interested in forest management.
Take it!
Audit it.
This is a great class! Take it! You will never ever regret it!

Keep up with the readings, go on as many of the field trips as possible, and study in a group for the mid-term and final because a lot of what you need to know comes from talking through different scenarios and that's much easier to in a brainstorming session.
Do the readings! Draw your own schematics along the way to integrate the wealth of information into something comprehensible for you.
Review lectures in early stage
TAKE IT!
I would highly recommend this course, especially if taken in the first year. The time requirements are somewhat hefty, but the course and all of the field trips are worth it.
Do the readings before class, and study in groups.
Absolutely take it, even if you're not an MF. You'll look at forestry and the forest products industry in a totally different light.
Know that it will take up a lot of your time. And that going on field trips will significantly help you on the exams!
Take it.
Ask all your questions!!
I would recommend participating on all field trips. They are extremely helpful and fun.

Take it! If you're at all interested in linking the theoretical to the practical, this is essential. Also, if you do or don't have a background in basic earth sciences, botany, and the connections between ecology and land management (and you want to make these connections) this class can help in a big way. I had lots of experience with plant ecology and I still found the holistic way in which material was presented to be very satisfying. I've taught basic landscape design courses before and I now feel like I know a better way to present material thanks to Mark's excellent teaching.Take it!
Since all concepts being taught are not so easy to follow, previewing and reviewing texts and given materials are necessary. Also group studying is the best effective way for following the class.
